resources.string: Seems you do not have root access on this device
We didn\'t found the iptables binary on this ROM… This application will not work.

You should reboot your device in order to ensure IPTables rules are properly applied.
 
 If you already have rebooted since orWall installation, you may have hit a bug…
 Please contact us on github! 
 You may also want to just apply bootup rules in order to test orWall — keep in mind this MAY let some leaks!
%d minutes, %d seconds until end of permission.
Ensure the init-script is always installed, even after an Android update.
Check this one in order to uninstall init-script and ensure it won\'t come back. Ever.
Manage some network options. Beware, you may go insecure!
Allows LAN to bypass the firewall and Orbot.\n \n WARNING: this will allow ALL apps to access LAN. And .onion won\'t resolve anymore.
Open TCP 5555 in both direction so that you may connect to your device overt network
Opens incoming TCP 22 port so that you may connect to your device through SSH.
Caution! Enabling this means *all* your secondary device traffic will go to the wild! That means you may get compromised!
Warning! This options means: all connections from secondary device will go straight to Internet, bypassing Tor!\n We strongly recommend to avoid this, unless you know what you\'re doing.
Caution! This will allow any app detecting Polipo port to connect to it and access freely to the Internet (through Orbot)!
Caution! This may leads to data leakage as the OS will probe network each time you connect to the Wireless!
Set up grace time in order to log in captive portals. Five minutes should be enough though.
Select applications with special rights, like your preferred browser app for Captive Portal authentication, or VoIP.
This browser will be authorized, on request, to bypass Tor in order to connect to a Captive Portal. You can activate the temporary bypass directly from the Menu.
Selected application will see its UDP traffic allowed outside of TOR.
Set Orbot proxy ports if you changed them in its configuration
This product is produced independently from the Tor® anonymity software and carries no guarantee from The Tor Project about quality, suitability or anything else.
Put your apps behind Orbot and block all unwanted traffic in one go.

This application uses an init-script.
 This script blocks all IP communication at boot time, preventing possible leaks from your device.
 We strongly recommend you accept this script.
 
 Script location is %s

This application uses an init-script in %s.
 Unfortunately, it seems your Android device doesn't support it.
 
 You may experience data leaks at boot time.
 
 We cannot do anything against that :(.

You're going to disable orWall.

 This means your device will allow all outgoing connections. As well, outgoing connections will not be forced to any anonymous proxy anymore.
 
 This may be dangerous!
 
 Please keep in mind deactivation will last until next reboot.
An error occurred, please contact the dev! #%d
Allow this application to bypass Proxy

Welcome to orWall!
 This wizard will let you learn what orWall can do and what it cannot. It will also give you some hints on what might or might not be done.
 
 orWall is not a firewall
 Keep it in mind. orWall will not replace AFWall nor DroidWall nor anything like that.
 orWall main aim is to allow you forcing apps though some local proxy when those apps don't know how to talk to this proxy; it will also allow you to prevent any leaks, using an init-script.
 
 How to use orWall
 You will find three panels:
 - Home
 - Apps
 - Logs (which isn't available for now)
 
 On the Home panel, you will find some main settings.
 From there, you are able to deactivate orWall (until next reboot), activate Tethering support (by default, orWall rules block that usage), as well as give a temporary authorization to a web browser to bypass the whole proxy thing, enable SIP application to send UDP requests, and enable Local Area Network (LAN) connections.
 
 On the Apps panel, you will find a list of your installed applications.
 
 Bellow you will find some information about current orWall status. Note that some switches may be disabled. This happens if, for some reason, an option isn't available on your device. It is also true for read-only settings.

Disable orWall
 This option let you deactivate orWall. Just keep in mind the deactivation will ends once you reboot your device. 
 Enable tethering
 You'll need to activate this option if you want to share your Internet connection from your device.
 Once this option is enabled, orWall will detect automatically when you enable the connection sharing, and activate a subset of firewall rules.
 
 It may take a while before this takes effect.
 WARNING! This option doesn't work as expected for now :(.
 
 Authorize browser
 This option allows you to lock up your device, while still being able to authenticate to some captive portal (like in hotels). An application you select through Settings>Special Applications will get an unlimited access to the network for a give time.
 Once you enable this option, a timer will start. Once it reaches the end of the grace time, the browser will be locked as previously.
 The grace time may be set in Settings>Network. Default value is 5 minutes.
 
 Enable SIP
 Toggling this option will allow a selected application to access remote hosts using UDP protocol.
 
 Enable LAN connections
 This will let you access to your Local Area Network.

Default behavior
 When you touch an app in the "Apps" tab, it will toggle its status: either the app can access the Net using Orbot, or it's locked out.
 The list view will refresh eventually when you come back to orWall later (this must be improved).
 
 Advanced settings
 A long touch will display a dialog in order to let you configure a bit more the app accesses.
 The following options are available for now:
 - Connection provider: let you chose between Tor and… well, Tor for now.
 - Connection type: either the application can be configured in order to use a local proxy, or you'll need to force it through the proxy.
 - Complete bypass: this option shouldn't be use at all, as it will allow the application to bypass completely your proxy, for life.
 
 Forced connection
 It uses iptables REDIRECT target in order to force the application through local proxy
 It will be shown on the application list as "TransProxy via [proxy]".
 
 Fenced connection
 This is for application aware of proxy settings. Some applications like Twidere, Lightning or ChatSecure already embed settings allowing you to make them go through Orbot or other proxies.
 Selecting this option in orWall will allow such application to connect to the Proxy, while preventing them to connect to other services.
 Imagine this option as a fenced road: You may access freely the content of the road, but you can't go elsewhere.
